reviewText:
It was a shame to be born with feet instead of wings. If we'd had wings we could have shared in the culture and traditions of every country around the world. But, thanks to It's Spring Again, we can share a delightful Russian artform with children who are growing up with the internet and ipads. And, here is a game that utilizes voice talant, art, and mechanics in a fluid way to engage kids everywhere. They might even pickup a little bit of a second language as well.

I'm probably getting the horse before the cart here, but this game is based on a puppet show, and the dlc (which is really a must-have in this game) includes a free video of the puppet show, along with an artbook. The artbook is filled with art from the game and the puppet show, as well as a concept sketchbook. The video is a live performance of a diaorama-type puppet show, sort of a 3D flannel board of the earth, which different stick puppets are attached to during the performance. This alone is well worth watching, though it is in Russian, and I couldn't locate the subtitle function on my plug-in. The acting was so dramatic and I'd already played the game through for a few hours, and you can tell right away the Earth is sleeping, even without knowing Russian. It is presented as metaphors.

But, that was just the dlc for this charming game. The game itself is it's own unique artform. It begins with giggling clouds, and a sunshine playing hide & seek. It calls for simple exploration type interactions to find the sun, while the narrator is telling the story in your choice of Russian or English. Each changing season is presented dramatically, while the gamer essentially operates the show himself. Nature is personified, with big faces. Even Earth" has a face and hands. The rainbow walks across the sky dome. And
date: those clouds are so giggly and fun. I can't wait to play this with my nephew in Kindergarten. Having worked with children for a lifetime
recommended: teaching Elementary Science and working with puppets
voteText: I fell in love with the artform and Science of the game immediately.\n\nThe  designers really put a lot of work into the format and chose to give two modes: an interactive game mode and an autoplay visual story mode. I started with the game mode
helpfulPercent: and was immediately drawn into the art of it
votesHelpful: which somehow reminds me of the stacking Russian dolls. The game mode has no ending
votesTotal: and not only has replay value
votesFunny: but one play through can engage a child (or adult) for quite sometime
commentsCount: with the cheerful sound-effects and basic Science concepts illustrated for young kids. The clouds literally drop the rain and snow on Earth
column16: for example.\n\nThe achievements come quickly. I got them after completing the game mode and the autoplay mode
column17: though it may be possible to get them without the game mode. I'm not sure about that
column18: since I started with the game mode. But
column19: the cards illustrate the characters from the story
column21: positive words on a color-changing sunshine. (Oh
column22: those arms on the sunshine!) The emoticons and backrounds are the seasons
column26: etc. all in tasteful illustrations. I'm obviously missing the Summer background
column28: and will have to wait until one shows up in the market.\n\nI doubt more words are neccessary for you to realize I highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a perfect game to share with a child."

reviewText:
8.0/10 - A 20 Minute Break From Life or Your Kids!

I'd say this game is perfect for someone 2-3 years of age or a stoned adult. I love the art style and animations in this one. It's the perfect way for a young mind to discover the seasons and how they change! I even found myself enjoying the process quite a lot!

There is a soothing narrator who walks you through the cycle of the seasons; you are just required to click on trees, grow flowers and watch the beauty unfold. It's only $1; so if you have a young kid or are just interested in a quick and cheap 100% achievement then this game is for you!

Worth the Full $1, even with this being only 15-20minutes.

reviewText: This seemed like it ought to be something my 3-year-old daughter could play. She had some difficulty with it, however. I was a little surprised, because she's good at games like Final Fantasy XIII or Binding of Isaac. I ended up taking over the controller from her, and while the game was challenging for me, I eventually beat it. Now I know a lot about the seasons! Lots of educational value, if only for limited age groups. Still, very good at what it does.

reviewText:
An interesting, educational and interactive story designed to teach children about the seasons..  Education is paramount to a child's development.  Nothing better than sitting back and watching your child beam a smile in your direction, it can brighten and warm even the coldest of people.

This game won't break the bank, and will probably give a child a couple of hours of entertainment...  Although when talking about children any parent knows that kids can get obsessed with just about anything..  Believe me I've gone through them all Barney, Teletubbies, (although DJ Lance Rock was awesome)  Elmo and the likes.

While I don't forsee this game/story taking over your child's life the same way something like Seseme street will, it can be a nice few hour escape for a parent who wants to take control over the television.

SO I'll say if now, buy this game, your kids will love playing games on the computer like they see Mommy and Daddy doing, you'll love the fact that something other than Television, or (forcing 5 DVD's into the dvd Player.. heck even the old Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich on the television trying to feed Cookie Monster... true stories)  coloring on the walls..

Sit back relax and enjoy the fact your child just helped you add another 100% game to your achievement list :-d

reviewText: It's Spring Again is a very short narrated story about the seasons. It features beautiful & colorful folk art with minor interactive elements (like clicking on trees so they bloom). After going through spring, summer, fall & winter it loops back to spring. Single playthrough takes about 10 minutes. There is also an autoplay option - no clicking required, just listening and watching.\n\nI would only recommend this game to very small children and unusual art enthusiasts like myself. Although be aware that there is only an English and a Russian narrator. A rather regrettable decision not to record more languages, especially how short the whole thing is.

reviewText:
It's Spring Again is a game based on a children spectacle, where they can participate, about seasons. The Collector Edition, which is a must-have, has the video subtitled in English of it and pictures, concept arts, etc..

The game is in Russian and in English, which means that kids from another language could be missing the educational side of It's Spring Again.

The storyteller is explaining what you can expect from a season: flowers during springs, fruits in summer, mushrooms in fall, snow in winter, etc.. Each scene is interactive: for example, the child has to find the sun behind the clouds or to make flowers growing on the ground by clicking on it, etc.. First, no help is activated, unless you click on help on the pause screen. Then, an hand will show you where to click. And as the winter is technically ending the story, there is in reality no end of the game. Indeed, you come back to spring and the cycle will continue, showing that it's infinite. The title takes all its sense: it's spring again!

The graphics are making me things of embroidery or anything that seems like it. Everything is anyway having eyes (trees, earth, sun, clouds). Also, the seasons are represented by a strange creature that is moving around. The voice acting in English is good and the sounds made when interacting will please children.

It's Spring Again is a short and good little game for 2-3 years old, with interesting bonus if you buy the CE. Even if it's in English, I do think that the pictures in the CE can be interesting to use in a classroom.

reviewText:
It's Spring Again is a short, educational game for children ages 2-5. It's based off of a successful puppet show, which the game mimics to perfection. The main focus and goal of the game is to help teach children about the four seasons, and the benefits of their cycle.

Throughout the game, the player will click on various elements, such as the sun, rain clouds, and trees, in order to help progress the cycle of the seasons. Starting in Spring, the player will help bring about the oncoming seasons, and when Winter hits the game then repeats by going back to Spring. During each season, the player will learn very simple facts; such as the sun getting warmer in the Summer, and leaves turning red and orange in the Fall.

Again, the game is aimed towards very young children. However, I feel that It's Spring Again could be a little more educational. The most your child will learn from the game is the order of the season cycle. It's nothing more than what they would learn in Kindergarten.

The art style is cute and simple, which is perfect for the target audience, and the female narrative is soothing and kid-friendly. The entire experience lasts roughly 5-6 minutes, so don't expect for it to keep your kids entertained for hours on end. There's hardly any replay value, although small kids do like to rewatch videos multiple times. For a buck, it's not a bad little Unity based game; just don't expect your kids to get a big lesson from it.

Rating: 3.0/5.0 - Average, can take it or leave it.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)

reviewText:
It's Spring Again (Collector's Edition)
This review was last edited after I had completed all 4 achievements

Short Review
An excellent, short point & click game with audio narration which I played with my 2 year old who absolutely loved it

Long Review
The game is short (around 15 minutes) and simply involves a narrator talking through the 4 seasons with stylised graphics showing what happens to the ground, trees & the sky during the seasons. You click on various aspects of the screen to move the story along.

You see rain & snow fall, leaves grow, change colour & fall, flowers grow, storm clouds gather and indeterrminable creatures walk across the screen as well as playing peek-a-boo with the ground and sun.

My two year old has not mastered the mouse yet so I had to do the mouse movement and clicking for him but he was able to point and tell me where I needed to click. The squeals of delight then we found the sun after chasing the clouds away and seeing the leaves fall off the trees were magical. We had to play the game through three times in a row and it as only with the arrival of tea time that I was able to drag my son away from the game.

ProsEnchanting story narration
Beautiful stylised graphics
Excellent for kidsConsUse of the term Fall instead of Autumn (The term Fall is not really used in the UK)Marks Out Of 5
5) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this
4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted
2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted
1) Not worth getting even if given away free

Where I got the game from
I got this game as part of the  Indie Gala [www.steamgifts.com] Friday Special Bundle #30

Platform Played On
Intel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, EasyAcc Mouse & Steelseries MERC keyboard. Played at 1440x900 resolution

3: I can't see any reason to raise it above this.  PEGI Ratings [www.pegi.info]

reviewText:
[ENG / FR]

[ENG]

It's Spring Again" is a little educational game that allows kids to learn the seasons cycle.
What can we say about that small experience?

+ Colorful characters
+ Sweet female narrator voice (You can disable it from the main menu)
+ Each season and its effects upon nature are described by the narrator
+ One achievement unlocked per season

- Very short: you can see the end of it in about 5 to 10 minutes.

"It's Spring Again" is a nice little game with a kind design intended for the younger kids.
It is one of the few games you can let your kid play with as soon as he / she is able to handle a mouse. Fun fact: A collector's edition is available for that game and its content is also available to buy separately. This means this game has a DLC
date:
which is pretty unusual for an educational game.

▬

[FR]

"It's Spring Again" est un petit jeu éducatif qui permet aux enfants d'apprendre le cycle des saisons. Que pouvons-nous dire de cette petite expérience?

+ Personnages colorés
+ Douce voix de la narratrice (Désactivable dans le menu principal)
+ Chaque saison et ses effets sur la nature sont décrits par la narratrice
+ Un succès débloqué par saison

- Très court: on en voit la fin en 5 à 10 minutes
- Pas de doublage français

"It's Spring Again" est un petit jeu sympathique avec un design mignon s'adressant aux jeunes enfants. C'est l'un des rares jeux que vous pouvez laisser entre les mains de votre enfant dès qu'il est capable de tenir une souris.
Fait amusant: une édition collector est disponible pour ce jeu
recommended: dont le contenu peut être acheté séparément. Cela signifie que ce jeu a un DLC

reviewText: Very nice storybook type of game that explains how the seasons work.  Uses the mouse to interact with objects on screen to help the seasons change.  Great game for 1 to 4 year olds to learn about spring,summer,fall and winter using wonderful graphics, sounds and narration.  Game is cheap so buy it and enjoy the experience with your kids.  Game is short, only lasts a few minutes but just perfect to do before bed or nap time.  I would love to see more games like this on steam, there are thousands of them for Android or Ipad so why not PC.  I remember lots of kids and learning games on the PC during the 90's and 2000's and I'm pretty sure they haven't stopped making them.  Would think this would be a market Steam could take advantage of, hint hint Gabe.

reviewText:
this game is pretty great if you have a toddler and a touchscreen.  if you have neither of those, it's an easy game to get 100% achievements in, it has cards, and it's only a dollar full price.

my 2-year-old daughter played all the way through and then did spring and summer again before wanting to do something else.  she spent 21 minutes with a couple hints from me about what she could try touching.  i think she'll probably want to play it again.  i think it would have been more frustrating for her if she would have had to use a mouse.

the strange animals representing were distracting and would occasionally animate as if you needed to do something with them, but they are non-interactive.  the ground on the other hand does need to be interacted with but the only indication is the narrator mentioning it.  other than that the animations and actions are very satisfying and the narration and sound are nice to listen to.

reviewText:
Supercute kids puzzle game at it's finest, point and click check ! haha :D
In this game you have to discover new seasons by clicking on things like trees and it's your job to make the sun shine at the trees so that they will drop leaves, snow or something else.
It's a very small game which is a plus-point actually, there are 4 achievements and you'll unlock all once you completed the game ( every couple minutes and completing a season will get you 1 achievement ) .
I completed the game in 10 minutes and it was fun, adoreable and nice to have been able to play this.


~> Positive points <~
Small game and fast to complete, very nice for achievement hunters
Cute handdrawn graphics
Nice story, you are in charge of the season switches, it's not a big story, but still a plus point
Cheap price, small game
~> Negative points <~
Short game and that's not good for some people, so i have to count that as a negative points aswell.
Price tag and value:
Since this game is just 0,99 and on sale 0.89 it's very worth it, you will have a great time with it, it's just 15 minutes but you'll feel happy afterwards, and it will earn you a perfect game on your profile haha :D

Summary;
Great game with a great price tag, i would recommend this game for all achievement hunters or people that have kids or people that want to relax a bit.
It's a kids game obviously but it's not wrong if you are older, it's very relaxing like i said and it's a nice addition to your steam collection.

Happy Winterveil haha :D
